questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents in the emergency room with dizziness and nystagmus. Examination reveals a loss of pain and temperature sensation over the right side of the face and the left side of the body. The patient exhibits ataxia and intention tremor on the right in both the upper and lower extremities and is unable to perform either the finger-to-nose or heel to shin tasks on the right. In addition, she is hoarse and demonstrates pupillary constriction and drooping of the eyelid on the right. Finally, the right side of her face is drier than the left. Which of the following artery block would explain the patient’s condition:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right posterior inferior cerebellar artery. This patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome), which occurs due to an ischemic event in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) or one of its branches. PICA supplies the lateral aspect of the medulla and the cerebellum. The symptoms described—such as loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the face (due to the trigeminal nerve involvement) and on the left side of the body (due to spinothalamic tract involvement), ataxia, intention tremor, and hoarseness (due to vagus nerve involvement), as well as Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, pupillary constriction, and anhidrosis)—are characteristic of PICA stroke. This makes right PICA blockage the most likely cause of this patient's condition, as the affected side of the body and face corresponds with the lesion's location on the right side of the medulla. Option B (Left posterior inferior cerebellar artery) is incorrect because the left PICA would typically affect the left side of the body and face, leading to symptoms such as loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side of the face and body, and left-sided ataxia. However, in this case, the patient exhibits right-sided symptoms, so the lesion cannot be due to left PICA occlusion. Option C (Right anterior inferior cerebellar artery) is incorrect because the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) primarily supplies the anterior and inferior parts of the cerebellum and the pons. Occlusion of this artery typically leads to cerebellar signs such as ataxia and dysmetria, along with cranial nerve involvement (such as facial weakness, hearing loss), but it does not produce the classic symptoms of Wallenberg syndrome, such as the pattern of sensory loss, hoarseness, and Horner’s syndrome, as seen with a PICA stroke. Option D (Basilar artery) is incorrect because basilar artery occlusion would lead to a more widespread, often bilateral, brainstem syndrome with severe impairment of vital functions, such as breathing and consciousness. The signs would include more global involvement, including both sides of the body, and would not be confined to the unilateral deficits seen in this patient, making basilar artery occlusion an unlikely cause in this case.

questions.text: Internal carotid artery at the bifurcation from the common carotid is -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lateral to the external carotid At the bifurcation of the common carotid artery, the internal carotid artery is located lateral to the external carotid artery. The common carotid artery bifurcates into the internal and external carotid arteries, with the internal carotid artery positioned laterally and the external carotid artery more medially and anteriorly. This anatomical relationship is important for surgical procedures and understanding carotid artery anatomy. Incorrect Answers: B. Medial to external carotid This option is incorrect because the internal carotid artery is not medial to the external carotid artery. It is positioned laterally at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery, not on the medial side. C. Post to external carotid This option is incorrect. The internal carotid artery is not posterior to the external carotid artery at the bifurcation. The external carotid is more anterior and medial compared to the internal carotid at the point of bifurcation. D. Anterior to external carotid This option is also incorrect because the internal carotid artery is not anterior to the external carotid artery. Instead, it is lateral to the external carotid artery at the bifurcation. The external carotid artery lies more medially and anteriorly than the internal carotid.

Correct Answer (B) Inferior anastomotic vein The Vein of Labbé, also known as the inferior anastomotic vein, is a venous structure that provides an anastomosis between the superficial middle cerebral vein and the transverse sinus. It plays an important role in the venous drainage of the brain, particularly in the lower part of the cerebral hemisphere. The vein runs along the lateral surface of the brain and connects the superficial venous system to deeper venous structures. This anastomotic vein is crucial in maintaining venous drainage, especially in cases of pathologies that alter normal venous flow. Hence, option B is correct. Incorrect Answers: A. Superior anastomotic vein The superior anastomotic vein (also known as the vein of Trolard) connects the superior cerebral veins with the superficial middle cerebral vein. It is not the same as the Vein of Labbé, which is an inferior anastomotic vein. Therefore, option A is incorrect. C. Superior cerebral vein The superior cerebral veins drain the superior parts of the cerebral hemisphere and empty into the superior sagittal sinus. However, the Vein of Labbé is not a superior cerebral vein, but an inferior anastomotic vein connecting the superficial middle cerebral vein to the transverse sinus. Hence, option C is incorrect. D. Superficial middle cerebral vein The superficial middle cerebral vein is one of the main veins of the brain, draining the lateral aspects of the cerebral hemisphere. While the Vein of Labbé does connect to the superficial middle cerebral vein, it is not the vein itself.

questions.text: Anterior Spinal artery is a branch of -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Vertebral artery. Explanation: The anterior spinal artery is a branch of the vertebral artery. It originates from the vertebral artery, which itself is a branch of the subclavian artery. The anterior spinal artery supplies the anterior portion of the spinal cord and is crucial for maintaining its blood supply. Incorrect responses: A. Internal Carotid artery: The internal carotid artery is primarily responsible for supplying blood to the brain, particularly to the anterior cerebral and middle cerebral arteries. It does not give rise to the anterior spinal artery, which comes from the vertebral artery. B. Basilar artery: The basilar artery forms from the fusion of the two vertebral arteries at the base of the skull. While it supplies the brainstem and other structures, it does not give rise to the anterior spinal artery, which is a branch of the vertebral artery before they merge to form the basilar artery. D. Labyrinthine artery: The labyrinthine artery is a branch of the basilar artery and supplies the inner ear, but it does not contribute to the blood supply of the spinal cord. It is unrelated to the anterior spinal artery, which is supplied by the vertebral artery.

questions.text: The vein of galen drains into –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Straight Sinus. Explanation: The vein of Galen, also known as the great cerebral vein, drains into the straight sinus. This vein is formed by the union of the two internal cerebral veins and runs along the midline to drain into the straight sinus, which is located at the junction of the falx cerebri and the tentorium cerebelli. Incorrect responses: A. IVC (Inferior Vena Cava): The inferior vena cava (IVC) collects blood from the lower body and returns it to the heart, but it is not directly related to the drainage of the vein of Galen. The vein of Galen drains into the venous sinuses of the brain, not the IVC. C. Superior sagittal sinus: The superior sagittal sinus is a major venous sinus that runs along the top of the skull and drains into the confluence of sinuses. However, the vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus, not the superior sagittal sinus. D. SVC (Superior Vena Cava): The superior vena cava (SVC) drains blood from the upper body into the right atrium of the heart. The vein of Galen does not drain directly into the SVC, as it is part of the intracranial venous system and drains into the straight sinus.

Correct Answer (B) Buccinator. Explanation: The buccinator muscle is not innervated by the trigeminal nerve. Instead, it is supplied by the facial nerve (CN VII). The buccinator is a muscle of facial expression that is responsible for compressing the cheek, which aids in actions like blowing and chewing. Therefore, the correct response is B, as the trigeminal nerve does not innervate the buccinator muscle. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Masseter The masseter is a muscle of mastication that is innervated by the mandibular branch (V3) of the trigeminal nerve. The masseter plays a key role in the elevation of the mandible for chewing. Therefore, the trigeminal nerve does supply the masseter muscle, making option A incorrect. C. Anterior belly of digastric The anterior belly of the digastric muscle is also innervated by the trigeminal nerve, specifically by a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), the mylohyoid nerve. This muscle plays a role in depressing the mandible and elevating the hyoid bone. Therefore, the trigeminal nerve does supply the anterior belly of the digastric muscle, making option C incorrect. D. Lateral Pterygoid The lateral pterygoid is another muscle of mastication that is innervated by the mandibular branch (V3) of the trigeminal nerve. It is responsible for the movement of the jaw during chewing, including the protrusion and lateral movements of the mandible. Therefore, the trigeminal nerve does supply the lateral pterygoid muscle, making option D incorrect.

Correct Answer (C) Superior sagittal sinus. Explanation: The superior cerebral veins primarily drain into the superior sagittal sinus. These veins collect blood from the cortical areas of the brain and carry it towards the superior sagittal sinus, which runs along the midline of the brain, inside the dura mater. The superior sagittal sinus is one of the major dural venous sinuses and ultimately drains into the confluence of sinuses at the back of the head. This makes the superior sagittal sinus the correct drainage point for the superior cerebral veins. Why the other options are incorrect: Great cerebral vein (Option A) The great cerebral vein (also called the vein of Galen) is a deep venous structure formed by the union of the internal cerebral veins. It drains into the straight sinus, not the superior sagittal sinus. While the great cerebral vein is closely related to venous drainage in the brain, it is not the destination for the superior cerebral veins, making this option incorrect. Vein of Galen (Option B) The vein of Galen is another name for the great cerebral vein, and it collects blood from deep brain structures. As mentioned earlier, it drains into the straight sinus, not the superior sagittal sinus. Therefore, the vein of Galen is not the drainage point for the superior cerebral veins. Inferior sagittal sinus (Option D) The inferior sagittal sinus runs along the bottom of the falx cerebri, but it primarily drains the deep regions of the brain and ultimately joins the great cerebral vein. It does not receive blood directly from the superior cerebral veins, which makes this option incorrect.

questions.text: Which of these is not a tributary of cavernous sinus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Superior petrosal sinus. Explanation: The superior petrosal sinus is not a tributary of the cavernous sinus. Instead, it acts as a drainage pathway, carrying blood away from the cavernous sinus to the transverse sinus. It is a connection between the cavernous sinus and the posterior venous system, but it does not contribute blood directly to the cavernous sinus. This role as an efferent venous structure rather than an afferent tributary distinguishes it from the other options. Why the other options are incorrect: Sphenoparietal sinus (Option A) The sphenoparietal sinus is a tributary of the cavernous sinus. It runs along the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone and empties directly into the anterior aspect of the cavernous sinus, contributing to its venous blood flow. Superficial middle cerebral vein (Option C) The superficial middle cerebral vein is a tributary of the cavernous sinus, either directly or indirectly via the sphenoparietal sinus or basal vein. This vein drains blood from the lateral surface of the brain into the venous system, including the cavernous sinus. Inferior ophthalmic vein (Option D) The inferior ophthalmic vein is also a tributary of the cavernous sinus. It drains venous blood from the orbit and connects with both the cavernous sinus and the pterygoid venous plexus, playing a significant role in venous drainage of the face and orbit.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused due to obstruction of PICA-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Obstruction to PICA can lead to Wallenberg syndrome but M/C artery causing Wallenberg syndrome will be vertebral artery. Option B-Medial medullary syndrome occurs due to anterior spinal artery obstruction. Option C-Brown Sequard syndrome occurs due to hemisection of spinal cord. Option D-Cerebellar atrophy can occur due to PICA obstruction but other cerebellar arteries can compensate hence,wallenburg syndrome is a better answer here.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in brown Sequard syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Brown sequard syndrome is characterised by involvement of- • Spino thalamic tract= loss of pain and temperature on contralateral side. • dorsal column = Ipsilateral loss of fine sensations(vibration and position). • Cortico spinal tract= Ipsilateral spastic palsy below the lesion. • Spinal nerve = ipsilateral flaccid palsy at the level of lesion.

questions.text: A patient presents with clinical features of Ataxia, vertigo. The following condition is due to thrombosis in which artery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Posterior cerebral artery thrombosis can lead to heteronymous hemianopia with macular sparing. Option B-Middle cerebral artery thrombosis can lead to broca's and wernicke's aphasia. Option C-Internal carotid artery itself divides into anetrior and Middle cerebral artery. Option D-In ataxia and vertigo, cerebellum is involved and the only cerebellar artery mentioned in options is superior cerebellar artery.

questions.text: Aneurysm of which artery causes visual defects by compressing at optic chiasma ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-Anterior cerebral,Middle cerebral and Anterior Choroidal do not usually cause compression at optic chiasma. Option D-Anterior communicating artery is locared near optic chiasma hence,Aneurysm of Anterior communicating artery causes visual defects by compressing at optic chiasma.if the compression is at the level of optics chiasma, it will cause bitemporal hemianopia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not branch of Facial Artery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C,D-Superior labial,Inferior labial and Lateral nasal are branches of facial artery. Option B-Mental artery is given by inferior alveolar branch of maxillary artery.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of Dysarthria, sensory loss of right side of face, right upper limb ataxia. There is sensory loss of left side of body without motor deficit. Which artery is involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given case scenario is of Lateral medullary syndrome:- Dysarthria-due to involvement of right 10th nerve. Sensory loss of right side of face-due to involvement of right spinal nucleus of trigeminal nerve. Right upper limb ataxia-due to involvement of right vestibular nucelus. Sensory loss of left side of body-due to involvement of right medial meniscus. Without motor deficit as pyramidal tract is not involved. The Most common artery involved in this syndrome is- vertebral artery > PICA

questions.text: Blood supply of the marked structure is:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Marked arrow is Splenium and Splenium is located at the junction of 2 blood supply territory i.e, ACA +PCA

questions.text: Artery supplying the marked area is a branch of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The marked area is of lateral part of medulla,whose involvment leads to wallenburg syndrome.which most commonly occurs due to lesion in vertebral artery>PICA. Option B-Basilar Artery supplies pons. Option C-Superior Cerebellar Artery supplies superior surface of cerebellum. Option D-Posterior Cerebral Artery supplies occipital lobe.

questions.text: A Patient presents with Nystagmus and vomiting. On examination, there is loss of pain and temperature on left side of face and right side of body. Also there is hoarseness of voice. Which artery is involved in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nystagmus and vomiting occurs due to cerebellum involvement. loss of pain and temperature on left side of face occurs due to left side spinal nucleus of trigemenial nerve involvement. loss of pain and temperature on right side of body occurs due to left side spinal meniscus involvement. hoarseness of voice occurs due to vagus nerve involvement. The above structures are involved in lateral medullary syndrome/wallenburg syndrome. This syndrome occurs most commonly due to vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

questions.text: What will be the patient's features if there is a lesion in Brodmann area 22?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Expressive aphasia (also known as Broca's aphasia) is a type of aphasia characterized by partial loss of the ability to produce language (spoken, manual, or written), although comprehension generally remains intact. A person with expressive aphasia will exhibit effortful speech. Option B-Receptive aphasia is also known as fluent, sensory, or Wernicke aphasia. The patient cannot understand words or recognize symbols, whether they are auditory, tactile, or visual. This form is related to an abnormality of the posterosuperior temporal gyrus of the Wernicke area [area 22]. Option C-Poor repetition of language is seen in both broca's and wernicke's aphasia. Option D-Poor naming s seen in both broca's and wernicke's aphasia.
